data.title: Midnight (1934)
data.meta_description: Jury foreman Edward Weldon's questioning leads to the death sentence for Ethel Saxon. His daughter Stella claims to have killed her lover, the gangster Garboni, just as Saxon was to sit in the electric chair.
data.text:
I thought I had seen most and knew about all of Humphrey Bogart's films but this was a new one to me.

Bogie was eighth billed when it was originally released and has a minor, though important, role. The film was re-released under the title 'Call it Murder' after he became famous with his name moved to above the title.

It's actually a very interesting morality tale which uses some sophisticated, imaginative camerawork for the time, and has lots of clever, creative cinematic ideas - although it mostly reminded me of a very well shot, studio-bound TV play of the fifties or sixties. You can certainly see its theatrical origins.

It opens with a very effective court-based scene where we…

This film is fairly minor in the scheme of things (here showing in its alternative title, 'Call It Murder'), but it is interesting to see a pre-stardom Humphrey Bogart during his long apprenticeship, as well as some Expressionist photography which keeps the interest (shadows, shots at odd angles, and so on).

OP Heggie plays Weldon, the jury foreman whose questions send a murderess, Ethel Saxton (Helen Flint), to the electric chair. She's killed her lover in a crime of passion which the all-male jury term as murder in the first degree. The remainder of the film follows the Weldons in particular through the evening of the execution, and that evening comes to a violent twist in which Stella Weldon (Sidney…
